core_definition: Enclosure philosophy - what happens when you draw a boundary; the act of encircling negates what is enclosed
key_implications: Drawing a circle around something changes its nature; boundaries create the negation of unboundedness
related_concepts: Membrane Concept / Boundary dynamics / Pemlik Tross work
notes: Connects to Dens instability - attempts to bound or define Dens regions may negate their essential properties

core_definition: Explanation for why Yeller Quarry is named as it is - beings transformed into geography
key_implications: Bodies of beings become the landscape; geography is accumulated embodiment
notes: Aunt Izzy uses this to explain Quarry naming; suggests transformation of living to geographic

core_definition: Yeller's anchor body - the others orbit around it; central body in the five-in-one
key_implications: Yeller is not five equal parts but one hub with four satellites; explains coordination of fivefold movement
notes: Key to understanding Yeller's nature as five-who-are-one

core_definition: Mysterious phenomenon causing far north villages to close - connected to five-nature
key_implications: Appearance of five-patterns causes village evacuation or closure; Volin/Damer/Roso/Corin affected
notes: May indicate Yeller influence spreading north; villages close when rumors arrive

core_definition: Identity is not fixed but performed - therefore unpredictable; Jackson demonstrated this
key_implications: Prediction models fail because identity is enacted not stored; reflexive subjects cannot be modeled
related_concepts: Reflexive Subjects / Jackson / Taxonomy of Failure
notes: Crost's key insight after prediction model failure - explains Jackson's unclassifiability

core_definition: Dens as pre-linguistic (before language applies) / Tower-desert as post-linguistic (beyond language)
key_implications: Language has bounded application; some spaces exist before or after linguistic categorization applies
related_concepts: Privacy / The Inner / Dens Mapping Principles
notes: Connects to "What if there were no such thing as the inner" question

core_definition: Two opposing approaches to classification - stone (solid categories) vs water (fluid boundaries)
key_implications: Stone School favors fixed classification; Water School favors dynamic/contextual categorization
notes: Represents ongoing tension in W1 scholarly approaches

core_definition: Intermediate or minor position in Stone/Water debate - perhaps small/granular categories
key_implications: May represent compromise position or alternative to Stone/Water binary
notes: Less documented than major schools; may be marginal or emerging position

core_definition: Fire-kindling-fire cycle - relationship between consuming and fueling; consumption enables continuation
key_implications: What burns becomes fuel for future burning; destruction enables creation
notes: Core Dens philosophical concept about cyclical transformation

core_definition: What happens when all thoughts become public - the end of interiority
key_implications: Loss of the inner as catastrophic event; privacy as fundamental to consciousness
notes: Connects to "What if there were no such thing as the inner" - ultimate privacy loss
